body: Some of the most congested parts of Brooklyn can expect "nightmarish traffic" virtually until the end of the century, transportation officials said yesterday, as reconstruction continues on the Brooklyn Bridge and work has begun on the Gowanus Expressway. title: FOR CHILDREN

title: Life on the Bottom Line: How Dinkins's Budget Affects Social Services; The Elderly: Old and in Need Of a Place to Go

body: Moments after helping bring one life into the world yesterday by delivering a baby in a Brooklyn subway station, two transit police officers rushed to a nearby stop and saved another by rescuing a woman who had thrown herself under a train. title: A Birth, a Near-Suicide, And It's Not Lunch Yet

body: STEADY customers at S. Scherer & Sons are expected to know: Tropical waterlilies are not sold there before the end of May, when pond temperatures reach 70 degrees. title: In Lieu of Grass, A Gurgle, a Ripple

body: The Box is back. Pale green with brown crosshatching, the Ebinger's cake box is stacked on the shelves of New York City supermarkets. Shoppers have gasped and paled at its resurrection. title: The Cake Box From Heaven (Brooklyn, of Course) Is Back

body: To the people who live in New York City, there is nothing abstract about the fiscal crisis anymore. Experts prescribe and politicians spar, but New Yorkers look past them at the city. What they see is loss. They see the city budget through the prism of their own lives and jobs, fears and urban pleasures. Regardless of what happens in the coming
title: For New Yorkers,Something Is Gone With Budget

body: As Maria Tisch heard Mayor David N. Dinkins tell New Yorkers on television on Wednesday that their libraries could close and that thousands could be laid off in the coming hard times, she was struck, she said, by a single thought: New York is no longer a place where dreams come true. "I felt the Mayor just looked me in the eye last night and said,
title: TV Audience Hears It Loud: New York Is in Big Trouble

title: Plan for Redistricting Is Faulted in Brooklyn

body: Making its sixth trip to the final four in the last six years and its fourth in that span to the final game, Abraham Lincoln High School came away last night with its second Public Schools Athletic League championship since 1986. The Railsplitters from Coney Island beat South Shore of Canarsie, 55-40, in an all-Brooklyn final of the boys' Class A
title: SCHOOLS; Lincoln Takes Title In P.S.A.L.

body: After five months of competition, 97 public high schools from the five boroughs of New York have been whittled down to just six survivors for the city championship basketball games of the Public Schools Athletic League at Madison Square Garden this evening. All three games will involve intraborough rivals. At 8 P.M., two Brooklyn squads meet in the
title: Three Finals In P.S.A.L.

body: MOST days Bob Kaye walks to work. An ornamental plasterer, Mr. Kaye lives in a turn-of-the-century brownstone in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Many of his jobs are in nearby houses with elaborate plaster ceiling medallions, moldings and wall ornaments in need of restoration and repair. "Plaster can last for years and years," Mr. Kaye said.
title: WHERE TO FIND IT; Plaster as the Frosting on the Cornice

body: Blue-skinned flying heroes rescue dolphins trapped in tuna nets. Mutant Ninja Turtles recommend that viewers avoid standing for too long in front of open refrigerators. title: TELEVISION; Cartoons for a Small Planet

body: Kenneth Fisher, a 38-year-old lawyer, claimed victory last night in the special election in the 29th City Council District in Brooklyn. Mr. Fisher said unofficial election results indicated that he had won by nearly 1,100 votes. Official results are to be released by the Board of Elections on Friday. Mr. Fisher's strongest opponent in the
title: Brooklyn Lawyer Defeats 8 Rivals In Special Race for a Council Seat

body: On Tuesday, voters in the 29th City Council District in Brooklyn will choose from among nine candidates who have spent a total of $500,000 in a race for an office that will cease to exist before the end of the year. Most of the candidates are liberal Democrats with barely distinguishable positions, but no trace of traditional party affiliations can
title: 9-Way Race for a Seat Soon to Vanish

body: Tuesday's nonpartisan election to fill the City Council seat in Brooklyn's 29th District is important. The winner will have a clear advantage in the fall election when the Council expands to 51 members and comes into its own under the new City Charter. The tone of the campaign has been far from uplifting and makes a choice difficult. Nonetheless,
title: Joan Millman for City Council

body: One man jumped to his death, another died of burns and eight other men were injured late Saturday in a fire in a residential Y.M.C.A. in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, the Fire Department said. The fire, believed to have started in a mattress in a room on the third floor of the seven-story brick building, was reported at 11:20 P.M. About 50
title: 2 Men Are Killed and 8 Hurt In Room Fire at Brooklyn 'Y'

title: Sweaters for the Transitional Season

body: Thousands of New York City teen-agers are playing dangerous variations on the age-old game of "chicken" in the subways, and two weeks ago a Brooklyn teen-ager was killed by a train he was trying to outrun, transit and school officials said. title: Youths Playing Deadly Game in Subway
